title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [8 april 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [8 April 1873]
text: 8 April 1873My dear waltWalti got your letter of sundaySunday and mondayMonday and the papers all come to day tuesdayTuesday i am always glad to get a letter from you walterWalter dear i wish i could get one every day O waltWalt if you could only say you was well once more i doodo pray for your recovery waltWalt and i doodo think you will be restored to health again it is very tedious to be so long disabled and your head you speak about being so bad how does it feel walterWalter dear do you have dissinessdizziness is it a heavy feeling either is bad enoughfenough i think any thing the matter with the head affects the whole system i wish you could have a change you have been so long and so much alone but i hope you dontdon't get down spirited) it sometimes comes on a person before they are aware of it) i got very nervous after matty smatty's death and have such a choakingchoking sensation but i know what makes me its thinking and fretting but i try to not think of things any more than i can help) georgeGeorge is up to his eyseyes in business he is very anxious to get all the work he can his house is begun the cellar is dug and the foundation laid he is going to build a three story brick house with an extentionextension parlor and dining room and kitchen and shed on the first floor the man does it all for i beleivebelieve its 38 hundred dollars puts in a range in the kitchen and bath and i believe priveeprivy and water closet there is no fireplaces except in the kitchen but one chimney peicepiece in the whole house that chimney peicepiece in the parlor he is to purchase himself no places for stove pipes) georgeGeorge says he thinks he will lose money on it) if we ever build waltWalt which i hope we shall i dontdon't think it will be quite so extensive) the cheapest house that you could build would be a 2 story house with 2 rooms below and 2 rooms above with a shed kichenkitchen with no fireplace in the house except in the kichenkitchen there to have a good size fireplace so walterWalter dear we can have our washing done) there is ways for ventilation without fereplacesfireplaces and its much cheaper to have stove pipes than firplaces what do you think of my plan waltWalt we couldentcouldn't have many visitors to stay all night well waltWalt i dontdon't know whether you will like to hear about our house affairs if you dontdon't want to hear about it dontdon't turn over the paper as its all on this sideyou remember i told you they thought Louisa was in the family way they think so still georgeGeorge and aunty i doubt if it is so but georgeGeorgey is very much pleased and they wontwon't let her hardly move yesterday she didentdidn't come down stairs all day mondayMonday) her aunt went to her daughter sundaySunday night and has only come back to day so i took up her meals all day yesterday but to day she has come down but lays on the sofa) i think her aunt will live with them Lou says georgeGeorge likes to have her here and he does i make no doubt he make a great time with her folks) i liked it better before her aunt came they want to be by themselveswalt what did you think of JosephenesJosephine's letter she is a very nice girli got a letter from helen to day she and her ma wants me to come to their house and stay a while but i shall never go of course but its very kind of themwrite again waltWalt this weekwe will hope for the best wontwon't we walterWalter dearthere was a man here to day that had put out some trees for georgeGeorge and georgeGeorge left the money to pay him and i went to the alley to pay him as louLou was lying down and i was lame and he said if i would get a pint of the best whiskey and put 2 teaspoonfuls of salt peter in it and take a teaspoonful night and morning it would help me and bathbathe with it too he said i dontdon't know as i shall get it but if you think of it walterWalter sometime when your doctor is there you may ask him about it i have heard of something simularsimilar being good for rhumatisrheumatismwe have the doctor here most every day but i dontdon't put faith in him Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [8 April 1873]
